Not true the last three weeks.* I applied the ACH method to this question last week. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Analysis_of_competing_hypotheses "In researching the history of Chinese aggression, it is evident that while posturing and defense build-up has been common, there has been very little in the way of direct attacks or limited engagements in the past three decades. In the eyes of author Tom Doctoroff, China’s bark is worse than its bite and “given an adolescent economy and an immature body politic, China must focus on domestic imperatives” (Doctoroff, 2013). It is the job of the analyst to identify any judgmental biases “which are often systematic rather than random, in a certain direction” (Kam, 2004). “Prediction is extremely difficult and is likely often to be erroneous, particularly when it refers to international relations and military affairs” (Kam, 2004). Keeping these things in mind when applying logic to this situation and following Heuer’s method of giving the most weight to arguments that compete against the obvious conclusions derived from available evidence, it was easier to identify signal from noise. Relevant variables that could have been overlooked when giving the most weight to the obvious become more noticeable when giving the most weight to the argument. This was of great importance when evaluating this problem set. There is abundant evidence that an engagement of some sort would happen between the PRC and India. If Heuer’s method of giving the most weight to information that weakens a hypothesis had not been applied, an analysis concluding that a conflict was in the future for them may have been reached. However, these hypotheses were easily argued against when the most weight was given to the information that weakened the engagement hypotheses. In fact, these weakening arguments turned into lynchpins, and two out of three lynchpins supported a political outcome. 2) If "lethal confrontation" is defined as "one or more people dying" then we've already seen a few altercations that could have easily have resulted in fatality (a thrown rock can do a lot of damage) and it's only just luck that they didn't.  To be clear, I'm thinking more of a fistfight or brawl that results in a fatality rather than an actual shoot-out, but things can escalate quickly.
3) The people on the front lines seem eager to fight.  When you have that many armed people all stationed in such close proximity to each other and both of them are spoiling for a fight, they will find a way to make it happen.  Maybe somebody will get drunk or high and do something that is misinterpreted.  Soldiers tend to be naturally aggressive people and this can spill out in interesting ways.
4) China has been very aggressive and expansionistic in previous years and is now going through a period of unforeseen weakness, due to the combination of pandemic, trade war, and natural disasters.  Other nations that lost power during China's heyday will naturally take advantage of China's weakened position to redraw the balance of power more in their favor - the only question is whether it happens in the next seven months, seventeen months, or twenty-seven months.  Seven months seems like a bit of an accelerated timetable (hence my low probability estimate) but it could happen.

This question is actually, though not explicitly, about border disputes. So we want to know (1) the likelihood of a military confrontation over the border and (2) the likelihood of fatalities in the event of such a dispute. Though I haven't been able to find hard numbers, it seems like military confrontations on the border are very common. Previous, quite similar clashes have not resulted in fatalities; it has been nearly half a century since an Indian soldier was killed. Many reports indicate that soldiers are not even armed. So- just keeping to fisticuffs on the border, I'd say there's something like a 5% chance of a fatality over the course of such an event. But then of course there's the idea that tensions are high, that both governments are nationalistic, and that China is newly militarily assertive. To me, this doesn't add much to the equation... a decision would have to be made at the highest levels of government to engage a nuclear power in overt combat. To what end? Standoffs sound reasonable, but previous such standoffs have concluded without fatalities. I agree that they could result in accidental incidents, so I add another 5%.

The only clash between China and India in the past which resulted in fatalities was the Sino-Indian conflict in 1967. After that incident, there were 5 incidents of stand-offs including this current one starting May 2020 (year of incidents: 2013, 2014, 2015, 2017, 2020).  Fights are likely to occur between troops, but are usually restricted to hands, or blunt weapons. It seems highly unlikely that there will be deaths resulting from fists or blunt weapons, although the forecast needs to be adjusted for the unlikely scenario of a lucky strike to the head. The recent border disputes have started since XJP and Modi came to power (2013 for XJP, 2014 for Modi). Both are seen as nationalists and strongmen who want to build their internal base up while maintaining a strong exterior to the world. This mentality has fueled the disputes over the past 5 years, although stopping short of ordering troops to attack each other with non-blunt weapons to prevent a regional war. Border disputes started in 2013 when XJP took power and wanted to exert control over China's military through a show of force (https://www.theatlantic.com/china/archive/2013/05/are-china-and-india-about-to-fight-over-their-border/275518/). 2014, 2015, 2017 clashes seemed to be about small incursions from construction equipment into disputed territory and usually ahead of Indo-Sino summits.  In 2020, China has ramped up its national security policies. All other nations except for US have not reacted strongly to the new nationalistic push by XJP. If Modi continues to stay on the sidelines, I do not believe that this clash will result in any fatalities as the orders from the top will continue to keep the troops in check.
